choices: ruling out specific medical conditions based on the absence of certain signs and symptoms.
the EMT’s prediction of the type of illness a patient has based on how the call is dispatched.
your awareness and concern for potentially serious underlying and unseen injuries or illness.
determining the underlying cause of a patient’s medical condition based on signs and symptoms.
front.question: An index of suspicion is MOST accurately defined as:

cards.back: your awareness and concern for potentially serious underlying and unseen injuries or illness.

choices: is a more contagious type of disease.
leads to chronic infection after exposure.
has a greater ability to produce disease.
is less resistant to treatment.
front.question: Hepatitis B is more virulent than hepatitis C, which means that it:
front.source: See Common or Serious Communicable Diseases

cards.back: has a greater ability to produce disease.

choices: joint pain, muscle aches, and blurred vision.
fever, rash, nausea, and difficulty breathing.
crushing chest pain, vomiting, and weakness.
headache, low back pain, and arm numbness.
front.question: Typical chief complaints in patients with an infectious disease include:

cards.back: fever, rash, nausea, and difficulty breathing.

choices: reassessing the nature of illness.
reviewing all treatment performed.
taking another set of vital signs.
repeating the primary assessment.
front.question: Reassessment of a patient with a medical complaint should begin by:

cards.back: repeating the primary assessment.

choices: are bleeding.
have a fever.
vomit.
cough.
front.question: Patients with tuberculosis pose the greatest risk for transmitting the disease when they:
front.source: See Common or Serious Communicable Diseases

cards.back: cough.

choices: 50-year-old woman with moderate obesity
12-year-old child with a fractured arm
39-year-old man with mild hypertension
68-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes
front.question: Which of the following patients is at greatest risk for complications caused by the influenza virus?
front.source: See Common or Serious Communicable Diseases

cards.back: 68-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes

choices: cardiac
endocrine
neurologic
respiratory
front.question: It is especially important to assess pulse, sensation, and movement in all extremities as well as pupillary reactions in patients with a suspected ___________ problem.

cards.back: neurologic

choices: Sexual practices
Drug allergies
HIV status
Recent travel
front.question: In addition to obtaining a SAMPLE history and asking questions related to the chief complaint, what else should you specifically inquire about when assessing a patient with a potentially infectious disease?

cards.back: Recent travel

choices: is typically limited to a focused exam for patients who are unconscious.
should be performed at the scene, especially if the patient is critically ill.
is not practical if the patient is critically ill or your transport time is short.
should routinely include a comprehensive examination from head to toe.
front.question: The secondary assessment of a medical patient:

cards.back: is not practical if the patient is critically ill or your transport time is short.

choices: is focused on the nature of illness, the patient’s chief complaint, and his or her symptoms.
is not as complex for the EMT because most patients typically present with classic symptoms.
almost exclusively focuses on physical signs that indicate the patient is experiencing a problem.
requires a thorough head-to-toe exam that involves a detailed assessment of all body systems.
front.question: In contrast to the assessment of a trauma patient, assessment of a medical patient:

cards.back: is focused on the nature of illness, the patient’s chief complaint, and his or her symptoms.

choices: direct your partner to apply oxygen via nonrebreathing mask.
squeeze the trapezius muscle to see if the patient responds.
assess breathing depth and determine the respiratory rate.
attempt to elicit a verbal response by talking to the patient.
front.question: Upon initial contact with a patient who appears to be unconscious, you should:

cards.back: attempt to elicit a verbal response by talking to the patient.

choices: meningitis.
MERS-CoV.
hepatitis.
tuberculosis.
front.question: A patient who presents with a headache, fever, confusion, and red blotches on his or her skin should be suspected of having:
front.source: See Common or Serious Communicable Diseases

cards.back: meningitis.

choices: the invasion of the human body by a bacterium that cannot be destroyed by antibiotics or other drugs.
a disease that can be spread from one person or species to another through a number of mechanisms.
a medical condition caused by the growth and spread of small, harmful organisms within the body.
any disease that enters the body via the bloodstream and renders the immune system nonfunctional.
front.question: An infectious disease is MOST accurately defined as:

cards.back: a medical condition caused by the growth and spread of small, harmful organisms within the body.

choices: quickly access the patient.
notify law enforcement.
contact medical control.
take standard precautions.
front.question: After sizing up the scene of a patient with a possible infectious disease, your next priority should be to:

cards.back: take standard precautions.

choices: failure to be vaccinated against any strain of hepatitis.
prolonged hospitalization, especially in an intensive care unit.
a history of a respiratory illness within the past 6 to 8 weeks.
prior exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
front.question: Factors that increase the risk for developing methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) include:
front.source: See Common or Serious Communicable Diseases

cards.back: prolonged hospitalization, especially in an intensive care unit.

choices: Asking questions related to the chief complaint
Refraining from asking open-ended questions
Trending of the patient’s vital signs over time
Focusing solely on how the call is dispatched
front.question: Which of the following will MOST reliably allow you to determine the nature of a patient’s illness?

cards.back: Asking questions related to the chief complaint

choices: typically does not require the EMT to contact medical control.
focuses on definitive care because a diagnosis can usually be made.
addresses the patient’s symptoms more than the actual disease process.
involves transport only until treatment can be performed at the hospital.
front.question: The primary prehospital treatment for most medical emergencies:

cards.back: addresses the patient’s symptoms more than the actual disease process.

choices: Primary assessment
Baseline vital signs
Index of suspicion
Medical history
front.question: When assessing a patient with a medical complaint, which of the following would MOST likely reveal the cause of the problem?

cards.back: Medical history

choices: Ibuprofen
Aspirin
Albuterol
Oral glucose
front.question: Which of the following medications would the EMT be LEAST likely to administer to a patient with a medical complaint?

cards.back: Ibuprofen

choices: wear a HEPA mask when treating any respiratory patient.
routinely place a surgical mask on all respiratory patients.
ask all patients if they have recently traveled abroad.
get vaccinated against diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis.
front.question: The BEST way to prevent infection from whooping cough is to:
front.source: See Common or Serious Communicable Diseases

cards.back: get vaccinated against diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis.
